summary: FBI interview with pilot David Rogers regarding his employment with Jeffrey Epstein, flight operations, aircraft ownership, and personnel. Rogers provides details about Epstein's travel patterns, staff, and denies witnessing underage females on flights.

persons.name: David Rogers
persons.context: Chief Captain for Epstein until January 2005, interviewed by FBI about flight operations and personnel. Provided flight logs and passenger manifests.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy individual employing pilots and staff, owner of multiple aircraft and residences, subject of FBI inquiry regarding travel and associates.

persons.name: Bruce M. Lyons
persons.context: Present during Rogers' FBI interview, representing him from the law firm Lyons and Sanders.

persons.name: Larry Visoski
persons.context: Full-time pilot for Epstein, took over as Chief Pilot from Rogers in January 2005 after a disagreement.

persons.name: Gary Roxburgh
persons.context: Occasionally assisted with flying Epstein in 2004 and 2005.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Previously handled Epstein's travel arrangements until late 2001 when replaced by another assistant.

persons.name: Miles Alexander
persons.role: Property Manager for Epstein's US Virgin Islands residence
persons.context: Employee responsible for managing Epstein's property in the Virgin Islands.

persons.name: Bryce Gordon
persons.role: Ranch Manager for Epstein's New Mexico residence
persons.context: Employee managing Epstein's ranch property in New Mexico.

persons.name: Janusz Banasiak
persons.role: House manager for Epstein's Palm Beach residence
persons.context: House manager employed for approximately a year or longer at Epstein's Palm Beach home.

persons.name: Alfredo
persons.role: Prior House Manager for Epstein's Palm Beach residence
persons.context: Former house manager at Epstein's Palm Beach home, last name unknown.

persons.name: Michael
persons.role: Prior House Manager for Epstein's Palm Beach residence
persons.context: Former house manager at Epstein's Palm Beach home, last name unknown, worked with Sally.

persons.name: Sally
persons.role: Prior House Manager for Epstein's Palm Beach residence
persons.context: Former house manager at Epstein's Palm Beach home, last name unknown, worked with Michael.

persons.name: Jean Brunel
persons.role: Associate connected to an Italian Modeling Agency
persons.context: Individual associated with an Italian modeling agency and connected to Epstein.

persons.name: Lance Calloway
persons.context: Epstein's chef for approximately the last year prior to the interview.

connections.description: Rogers was employed as a pilot for Epstein since July 1991, serving as Chief Captain until January 2005.
Lyons represented Rogers during his FBI interview.
Both were pilots for Epstein; Visoski replaced Rogers as Chief Pilot.
Maxwell was Epstein's personal assistant handling travel arrangements until late 2001.
Visoski is a full-time pilot for Epstein and became Chief Pilot.
Hammond is a full-time pilot employed by Epstein.

events.title: FBI Interview of David Rogers
events.description: FBI agents interview pilot David Rogers at the Palm Beach County Resident Agency's office regarding his employment with Jeffrey Epstein, flight operations, and personnel.

events.title: Rogers Demoted as Chief Pilot
events.description: David Rogers was demoted from Chief Captain after a disagreement with Epstein about landing techniques at Palm Beach International Airport, resulting in decreased pay.

events.title: Maxwell Replaced as Personal Assistant
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was replaced as Epstein's primary personal assistant handling travel arrangements in late 2001.

keyFacts: David Rogers provided FBI with his 2004-2005 personal aircraft log books and passenger manifests for Epstein's Boeing 727 (N908JE) and Gulfstream (N909JE).
Rogers stated passenger manifests sometimes listed travelers only by gender ('male' or 'female') or as 'passenger' when names weren't obtained.
Rogers denied witnessing any underage females on Epstein's aircraft but acknowledged 'many' females aged 21-23.
Epstein owned aircraft through subsidiary companies: JEGE, Inc. (Boeing 727) and Hyperion Air, Inc. (Gulfstream), plus a Bell 407 helicopter.
The document lists numerous current and past employees of Epstein, including property managers, house managers, assistants, a chef, and a personal trainer.
